title: Trainsignal Cisco CCENT - ICND1 100-101
description:

Authored by: Ross Bagurdes

In this course, the student will learn the fundamental concepts of networking, and then immedately apply this knowledge to the configuration of a router and switch. By the end of the course, the student will have enough knowledge to set up a network environment that has multiple subnets over multiple virtual LANs (VLANs), use network address translation (NAT) to connect to the Internet, and hand out IP addresses automatically. Additionally, the student will take a deep dive into IP addressing, using binary, to really gain a fundamental understanding of how endpoints are addressed. All you need as a prerequisite is a willingness to learn and basic computer skills.
Lesson 0: Getting Started with ICND1 (100-101)
Lesson 1: Introduction to Data Networking
Lesson 2: Introduction to Network Protocols
Lesson 3: Network Models
Lesson 4: The OSI Model and Encapsulation
Lesson 5: TCP and UDP
Lesson 6: Introduction to Binary
Lesson 7: Introduction to IP Addressing
Lesson 8: Router Basics
Lesson 9: Router Configuration
Lesson 10: SSH and CLI Tips
Lesson 11: Routing Packets
Lesson 12: Ethernet and Switching
Lesson 13: Switch Configuration
Lesson 14: Other Data Link Layer Protocols and the Physical Layer
Lesson 15: Introduction to Subnetting
Lesson 16: Subnetting Examples
Lesson 17: Variable Length Subnet Masking (VLSM)
Lesson 18: Building the Routing Table
Lesson 19: Route Summarization
Lesson 20: Dynamic Routing
Lesson 21: Introduction to OSPF
Lesson 22: Virtual LANs (VLANs)
Lesson 23: VLAN Trunks
Lesson 24: Inter-VLAN Routing
Lesson 25: Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol (DHCP)
Lesson 26: Static Network Address Translation (NAT)
Lesson 27: Dynamic Network Address Translation (NAT)
Lesson 28: Access Control Lists (ACLs)
Lesson 29: Extended Access Control Lists
Lesson 30: Switch Security: Native VLANs, DHCP Spoofing, and DTP
Lesson 31: Switch Security: Switchport Port-security
Lesson 32: Network Device Security
Lesson 33: IPv6
Lesson 34: Next Steps

About the author:
Ross has had a diverse career. He has a Structural Engineering degree from Milwaukee School of Engineering, but gave up the career shortly after graduating from college. Beginning in 1997, Ross began officially working in IT, implementing and supporting a paperless work order system for a Natural Gas Utility in Illinois. Since then, Ross has spent his years teaching and managing data networks. Ross spent 7 years at University of Wisconsin Hospitals and Clinics, supporting and managing the large enterprise network. He now has returned to teaching at Madison College in Madison, Wisconsin.
